text:
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mary Jane Tait

Present Address: 1905 St. Clair, Elster, Alberta, Sask.

Pioneer Address: Macdonald, Sask.

The year you came to Saskatchewan: 1905

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE:

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1941, and most of the questions are about that early period although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realise that not one person will not be able to answer all questions so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on this questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questions answered will be recorded in the Saskatchewan Archives Office as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
SASKATOON, Sask.
YOUR EXPERIENCE OF EARLY SCHOOL ACTIVITY

1. Persons answering this questionnaire will have learned of school life in the early days in Saskatchewan in different ways. In order that your answers may be of value in making a history of pioneer schools, please put a check mark beside each of the following statements to you, giving dates whenever possible:

   You went to school in Saskatchewan
   Your children attended school
   You taught school
   Other (specify)

2. If you experience in different capacities took you into more than one community (for example, if you taught in various districts or taught in one place, then moved and lived in another part of the province), make it clear in your answers which district or town you are referring to in each question. Or if you have any doubt about which of these you intended to deal with, fill in this questionnaire again. If you would like separate questionnaires for different towns which you visited, please ask for another copy.

BUILDING AND EQUIPMENT

2. Was school held in your district before a school building was erected? No

If so, describe the arrangements, telling where school was held, how many pupils attended, who the teacher was, how long this system continued, as well as any other details which you may remember.

3. When was the school in your district built? 1905

4. Who designed and built the building?

5. What material was the school made of (logs, lumber, stone or other materials)? Lumber - Planks - Steel on Eddy (Husky Bay Style)

6. What was the size of the building? 25' x 40'

7. Were there cloakrooms for coats, or were they hung at the back of the classroom? Hung at the back of Classroom

8. Did the school have a basement? No

What use was made of it?

If the building included any other rooms besides those mentioned in this question, tell what they were used for, and their sizes.
YOUR EXPERIENCE OF EARLY SCHOOL ACTIVITY

1. Persons answering this questionnaire will have learned or school life in the early days in Saskatchewan in different ways. In order that your answers may be utilized, please fill out the following questions.

   You went to school in Saskatchewan.
   You attended school in another province.
   You taught school in another province.
   Other (specify):

2. If your experience in different capacities took you into more than one community (for example, if you taught in various districts, or taught in one place, then moved and lived in another part of the province), make it clear in your answers which places you visited.

3. If so, describe the arrangements, telling where school was held, how many pupils attended, who the teacher was, how long this system continued, as well as any other details which you may remember.

BUILDING AND EQUIPMENT

2. Was school used in your district before a school building was constructed?

   Yes
   No

3. When was the school in your district built?

4. Who designed and built the building?

5. What material was the school made of? (logs, lumber, stone or other)

6. What was the size of the building?

7. Were there classrooms for coats, or were they hung at the back of the classroom?

8. Did the school have a basement?

9. What use was made of it?

If the building included any other rooms besides those mentioned in this question, tell what they were used for, and their sizes.
Were there any additions or major alterations in the school?

If so, explain what these changes were, giving sizes, and explain the reason (that is, was it because of increase in number of pupils, or for extra convenience, such as adding a porch or coal shed).

6. Is this first school building still in use? No - New school built.

If not, give the reason (burned, new school built, school closed because of lack of pupils, etc.) Give dates if possible.

7. Describe the window arrangement in the classroom, telling how many, how placed (all on one side, or two sides of room, etc.), whether provided with blinds, etc.

8. Was there any kind of lamp in the school, or other provisions for artificial light? Explain.

9. Describe the school equipment, - desks, (kind and number), blackboards, maps, etc.

10. How many families with children of school age were active in getting the first school started?

How many children of school age were there in the school?

How many bachelors or others in the district helped in establishing the school? Explain.

Was there any opposition within the community towards the idea of starting a school? Explain.

ORGANIZATION AND ADMINISTRATION

11. How many families with children of school age or younger were active in getting the first school started?

Was there any opposition within the community towards the idea of starting a school? Explain.
7. Were there any additions or major alterations in the school lately? If so, explain what these changes were, giving sizes, and explain the reason (that is, was it because of an increase in number of pupils, or for extra convenience, such as adding a porch or coal shed).

8. In this first school building built in [year], No. [number] was used for [purpose]. If not, give the reason (burned, new school built, school closed because of lack of pupils, etc.) Give dates if possible.

9. Describe the window arrangement in the classroom, telling how many, how placed (all on one side, or two sides of room, etc.), whether provided with blinds, etc.

10. Describe the school equipment, - desks, (kind and number), blackboards, mops, etc.

11. How many families with children of school age or younger were active in getting the first school started?

How many children of school age were there in the school?

How many teachers or others in the district helped in establishing the school? Explain.

Was there any opposition within the community toward the idea of starting a school? Explain.
12. Describe the steps taken towards the starting of the school.

13. What was the name and number of the school district? Who or what was the district named after?

Was there any difficulty or disagreement over choosing this name?

14. How many women, if any, were on the first trustees board set up? How many women have served on the boards since? Give dates if possible.

How many bachelors were on the first board?

Since?

15. Was it difficult to get people to act as trustees? Explain.

16. Were school trustees usually parents with children going to school? Has it through that the teacher "favoured" the children of trustees? Did the trustees try to do their best for the school, or were they mainly interested in "keeping down expenses"? Explain.

17. Were the ratepayers' annual meetings well attended?

18. How long did teachers usually stay at school - a year, less than a year, for several years?

19. Did the teacher "board around" from one place to another, have a regular boarding place, a teacherage, etc.? Explain.

20. How far did she or he have to go? How much was charged for board? Perhaps

21. In choosing a teacher, was preference shown to either sex? No

Did a man receive a higher salary? No

How much were the salaries? Was a preference shown to any nationality or religion? Explain.

No one in Community wanted Protestant Teacher Had To be Protestant. The Community was Protestant.
12. Describe the steps taken toward the starting of the school.

13. What was the name and number of the school district? How did it get its name?

Who or what was the district named after?

Was there any difficulty or disagreement over choosing this name?

14. How many women, if any, were on the first trustees' board set up?

How many women have served on the board since? Give dates if possible.

How many bachelors were on the first board?

Since?

15. Was it difficult to get people to act as trustees? Explain.

16. Were school trustees usually parents with children going to school?

Was it through that the teacher "favoured" the children of trustees?

Did the trustees try to do their best for the school, or were they mainly interested in "keeping down expenses"? Explain.

17. Were the ratepayers' annual meetings well attended?

18. How long did teachers usually stay at school - a year, less than a year, for several years? Average of 2-3 years.

19. Did the teacher "board around" from one place to another, have a regular boarding place, a teachers' home, etc.? Explain.

How much was charged for board? Why?

20. How far did she or he have to go? From... to...

21. In choosing a teacher, was preference shown to either sex? No

Did a man receive a higher salary? No

How much were the salaries?

Was a preference shown to any nationality or religion? Explain.

No one in community wanted Protestant Teacher

Had to be Protestant. The community was
22. What was the approximate age of most teachers in your school? In choosing a teacher, was preference given to any particular age group? Explain.

What were the teachers like? Mix with people in the district, take part in community activities, etc.? 

Did many of the teachers marry someone in the district? 

How much did older pupils help the teacher with smaller ones at school? Tell whether it was a regular custom, or only once in a while, and what they did to help—mark arithmetic questions, hear reading, give spelling, etc.

24. Were report cards sent to parents?

How often?

Were any other means used to let parents know how their children were doing in school? Explain.

Were parents usually interested in finding out how their children were doing, and in what activities were being carried on in school? Explain.

25. How often did the school inspector visit the school?

What means of travel did he use?

Were his visits considered of benefit to the school? Explain.

Was the character of the inspector such that he was respected by trustees, teachers, and others in the district? Explain.

26. Who did the janitor work and let the fires?

Who looked after the fire during the day?

What kind of a stove or furnace was used?

What fuel was used? Wood, etc.)?

During cold weather, was the school always warm enough in the morning to start school on time?

If not, what did the pupils do to keep warm—play running games, etc.?

27. Did school always start at 9 a.m., and close at 3:30 p.m.? If not, tell what changes were made, and reasons. (For example, if opening time in winter was 9:30 a.m., etc.)
22. What was the approximate age of most teachers in your school? In choosing a teacher, was preference given to any particular age group? Explain.

What were the teachers like, mix with people in the district, take part in community activities, etc.? 

23. Did many of the teachers marry someone in the district? If so, how did they meet?

How much did older pupils help the teacher with smaller ones at school? Tell whether it was a regular custom, or only once in a while, and what they did to help—mark arithmetic questions, hear reading, give spelling, etc.

24. Were report cards sent to parents? How often? Were any other means used to let parents know how their children were doing in school? Explain.

Were parents usually interested in finding out how their children were doing, and in what activities were being carried on in school? Explain.

25. How often did the school inspector visit the school? What means of travel did he use? Were his visits considered of benefit to the school? Explain.

Was the character of the inspector such that he was respected by pupils, teachers, and others in the district? Explain.

26. Who did the janitor work and let the fires? Who looked after the fire during the day? What kind of a stove or furnace was used? What fuel was used? Where was fuel kept (a separate building, in school building, etc.)? During cold weather, was the school always warm enough in the morning to start school on time? If not, what did the pupils do to keep warm (play running games, etc.)? Did school always start at 9:00 A.M., and close at 3:30 P.M.? If not, tell what changes were made, and reasons. (For example, if opening time in winter was 9:30 A.M., etc.)
28. To what extent did the school board buy text books to supply free to the pupils? 

29. How many pupils attended your school? 

30. How far were you from school? 

31. Do you ever remember the pupils ever having to stay at school all night because of a blizzard, spring time floods or other such conditions? 

Describe the circumstances? 

32. Was it the custom to have the school closed during the winter months? 

In the fall or other time so children could help with work at home? 

33. Was the school ever closed because of epidemics of diseases? 

Tell what diseases, and give dates and length of time school was closed. 

34. How much did pupils have to miss school to help with work at home? 

Because of bad weather? 

Extreme cold weather.
28. To what extent did the school board buy text books to supply free to the pupils? 

29. How many pupils attended your school? 

30. How far were you from school? 

31. How did most of the children in the district get to school (walking, riding horsecars, etc.)? 

32. Was there a barn for the horses? 

33. Do you ever remember the pupils ever having to stay at school all night because of a blizzard, spring tide floods or other such conditions? 

34. Describe the circumstances. 

35. Was it the custom to have the school closed during the winter months? Explain. 

36. In the fall or other time so children could help with work at home? 

37. Was the school ever closed because of epidemics of diseases? Tell what diseases, and give dates and length of time school was closed. 

38. How much did pupils have to miss school to help with work at home? Because of bad weather? Sometimes when extremely cold weather.
35. What was the attitude of most of the children towards going to school (disliked it, like it because of the teacher, other pupils, got away from work at home, learning to read books, etc.)? Explain.

36. Were any children in your district taught at home instead of coming to school? Why (distance, weather, not wish children to associate with others, etc.)?

CLASSROOM ACTIVITIES

37. Did the subjects, reading, writing, and arithmetic, make up most of the school program? Explain.

38. Was reading taught mostly by "sounds" or by some other method?

39. How large a part did oral reading play in school work (how often did pupils in lower grades read aloud from their readers, in what grade was this discontinued, did pupils ever read aloud from other books besides their readers, did pupils in higher public school grades ever read aloud, and from what books, etc.)?

40. Were pupils given much "memory work" to learn from their readers or from other books? Explain.

Did the teacher usually ask pupils to recite memory work, or write it on the blackboard, or in notebooks, etc.?

41. Describe the nature of writing lessons and practice—were they from copy books, from the readers, writing so many lines of tall letter, etc.? How much was printing used in the primary grades instead of writing?

42. Describe any particular features of arithmetic classes which you remember. (For example, were questions written on the blackboard before being worked out, were answers written on the blackboard, were problems worked out on the board, etc.)

Many questions on Arithmetic.

Teachers were questioned on Arithmetic.
35. What was the attitude of most of the children towards going to school (dislike it, like it because of the teacher, other pupils, get away from work at home, learning to read books, etc.)? Explain.

36. Were any children in your district taught at home instead of coming to school? If so, why (distance, weather, not wish children to associate with others, etc.)? Explain.

CLASROOM ACTIVITIES

37. Did the subjects, reading, writing, and arithmetic, make up most or all of the school program? Explain.

38. Was reading taught mostly by "sounds" or by some other method?

39. How large a part did oral reading play in school work (how often did pupils in lower grades read aloud from their readers, in what grade was this discontinued, did pupils ever read aloud from other books besides their readers, did pupils ever read aloud from school grades ever read aloud, and from what books, etc.)?

About Grade Three:

40. Were pupils given much "memory work" to learn from their readers or from other books? Explain.

41. Did the teacher usually ask pupils to recite memory work, or write it on the blackboard, or in notebooks, etc.?

42. Describe the nature of writing lessons and practice; were they from copy books, from the reader, writing of many lines of tall letter, etc.? Counting lines of copy used.

How much was printing used in the primary grades instead of writing?

43. Describe any particular features of arithmetic classes which you remember. For example, were questions written on the blackboard, used, was addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, extremely large numbers required, was much use made of board games, board numbers in arithmetic?

Teachers wrote questions on their board.

Many questions in green paint.
43. Did you have much formal grammar (Parsing words, picking out subject, predicate, object, etc.)? Yes - Incorrected.

44. Describe any activities designed to improve the manner of speaking and writing of the pupils, such as written exercises in the use of correct words, or exercises of the teacher to improve the spoken English of the pupils.

Some Features Among the Students

45. Were the pupils very often asked to write compositions, and how important a part did this activity play in school?

46. Did any of the teachers encourage pupils to write poetry?

47. Did pupils do much speaking before the rest of the school, such as telling stories, giving talks, holding debates, etc.?

48. Was any language besides English taught in any of the public school grades? Give details.

What proportion of the children, if any, could not speak English when they started school?

Were they given special instruction to help them learn English, or were they left alone to "pick it up" from the other children?

49. As nearly as you can remember, tell how much the following subjects were taught, only once in a while if a teacher was interested in that subject. Add any details you can remember as to how they were taught, and what activities were carried on in connection with these subjects:

History Geography Daily
Literature Nature Science Music
Art Music Physical training Once A Week
43. Did you have much formal grammar (parsing words, picking out subject, predicate, object, etc.)? Yes. [Handwritten note]

Describe any activities designed to improve the manner of speaking and writing of the pupils, such as written exercises in the use of correct words, or attempts of the teacher to improve the spoken English of the pupils.

Some debates among the students.

45. Were the pupils very often asked to write compositions, and how important was this activity?

46. Did any of the teachers encourage pupils to unite poetry?

47. Did pupils do much speaking before the rest of the school, such as telling stories, giving talks, holding debates, etc.? Not too much.

48. Was any language besides English taught in any of the public school grades? Give details.

What proportion of the children, if any, could not speak English when they started school?

Were they given special instruction to help them learn English, or were they left alone to pick it up from the other children?

49. As nearly as you can remember, tell how much the following subjects were taught at all times. If a teacher was not taught at all times, give a little of what details you can remember as to how it was taught, and what activities were carried on in connection with these subjects:

History Geography Daily

Literature Nature Science Music

Art Physical training

1/2 hour per week with some teachers.
50. Tell about any other subjects studied at school, or activities carried on in connection with school work, which may have not already been mentioned.

51. Were slates ever used in your school? Yes

If so, when was their use discontinued? 2nd & 3rd Grade

52. What were the usual punishments for misbehavior?

How much did teachers make pupils learn memory work as punishment? Not used often

Were they ever ordered to write lines as punishment? Yes

Were there any incidents in which parents objected to the form or punishment given by the teacher? No

What was done about it?

53. What religious observance was carried on in school, such as opening school with Lord's prayer, hymn, etc.? Sunday School Prayer

SCHOOL HEALTH CONDITIONS

54. What arrangements were made for eating the noon lunch? (Did pupils sit in their seats, go outside, etc.)?

In summer? Sat in their seats. Some small children went outside.

In winter? Sat in their seats.

55. Did pupils wash their hands before eating? Yes

Describe the washing arrangement so.

This was Tuesday.

56. What tools were brought in school lunches? Sandwashes - Game, dresses - very little food.

57. Were pupils allowed to eat part of their lunch at recess time? Yes

58. Was there always drinking water at school? Yes

Where was water secured for the school? Well at P.M. House

Who carried it? Pupils

59. Tell what toilet accommodation there was. (outside toilets, separate ones for boys and girls?) Outside toilets, separate classes for boys and girls.
50. Tell about any other subjects studied at school, or activities carried on in connection with school work, which may have not already been mentioned.

51. Were slates ever used in your school? If so, when was their use discontinued?

52. What were the usual punishments for misbehavior?

53. How much did teachers make pupils learn memory work as punishment?

54. Were they very often required to write lines as punishment?

55. Were there any incidents in which parents objected to the use of punishment by the teacher?

56. What was done about it?

57. What religious observance was carried on in school, such as opening school with Lord's Prayer, hymn, etc.?

SCHOOL HEALTH CONDITIONS

58. What arrangements were made for eating the noon lunch? (Did pupils sit in their seats, go outside, etc.? In summer? In winter?)

59. Did pupils wash their hands before eating?

60. Describe the washing arrangements.

61. What tools were brought in school lunches?

62. Were pupils allowed to eat part of their lunch at recess time?

63. Was there always drinking water at school?

64. Where was water secured for the school?

65. Who carried it?

66. Tell what toilet accommodation there was. (outside toilets, separate ones for boys and girls?)
SCHOOL GROUNDS, GAMES AND ENTERTAINMENT

60. How large was the school yard? Yes.

Was it fenced?

Describe any efforts at improvement or the school yard, such as planting trees, flowers, gardens etc., give dates if possible.

61. What games did the pupils usually play in cold or rainy weather?

In good weather?

What equipment did they have for games, and how was it secured?

62. Were any school teams or clubs organized before 1916 to play against teams from neighboring schools?

Describe any details you remember about arrangements for such games.

63. Were there divisions or "sides" taken among the pupils because of racial differences, or were some children "picked on" because of that or other reasons?

64. Tell what you remember about the school library, as to number and kind of books.

How much use did the pupils make of the library during school hours? Also, when used after school hours?

65. Was Friday afternoon, or some other time, usually used for special activities, such as spelling, art, music or geography matches, meetings of a school society, or other activities?

Explain.

DISTRICT SOCIAL LIFE

66. When did the annual Christmas concert and tree become an established custom in your school, and in neighboring schools?

How was money secured for the expenses of the concert, and for gifts and treats for the children if these were provided?
SCHOOL GROUNDS, GAMES AND ENTERTAINMENT

60. How large was the school yard? Yes

Was it fenced? Yes

Describe any efforts at improvement of the school yard, such as planting trees, flowers, gardens, etc.

61. What games did the pupils usually play in cold or rainy weather?

In good weather? Baseball - Boys played this game. The prisoners' base - they played this game. The prisoners' base - they played this game.

What equipment did they have for games, and how was it secured?

Outside was used with yarn. Outside was used with yarn.

62. Were any school teams organized before 1914? If so, play against teams from neighboring schools?

For what game or games?

Describe any details you remember about arrangements for such games.

63. Were there divisions or "sides" taken among the pupils because of racial differences, or were some children "picked on" because of their or other reasons?

64. Tell what you remember about the school library, as to number and kind of books.

How much use did the pupils make of the library during school hours? Very little.

How much use did the pupils make of the library during school hours? Very little.

65. Was Friday afternoon, or some other time, usually used for special activities, such as spelling, arithmetic or geography matches, meetings or a school society, or other activities?

Explain.

Yes - Saturday Matches - Geography matches

DISTRICT SOCIAL LIFE

66. When did the annual Christmas concert and tree become an established custom in your school, and in neighboring schools?

How was money secured for the expenses of the concert, and for gifts and treats for the children? All these were provided by...
67. Tell what you remember of the Christmas concerts, type of program, when it was held, if a platform was erected for it, and other incidents connected with it.

68. To what extent was the teacher's ability as a teacher judged by the success of her Christmas concert? Give details.

69. Was there much neighborhood rivalry as to which school could put on the best concert? Explain.

70. Tell about any other parties or special events held on particular days, which were a part of the school activities such as Valentine or Halloween parties, parents visiting the school, etc.

71. To what extent was the school building used as a community hall, for church, dances, concerts, organization meetings, special events, etc.? Describe.

72. Was the school yard used for school or community picnics, ball games, etc.? Describe.

GENERAL

73. What differences were there in the way the school was conducted in the first years you were here as compared with the way it is conducted today?

74. Did any teachers or pupils from your district achieve distinction or become well known in later years? Give names and details.

75. Describe any special or unusual happenings or incidents in connection with school affairs in your district not already mentioned. (Use back of page or extra sheets if necessary.)
67. Tell what you remember of the Christmas concerts, type of program, when it was held, if a platform was erected for it, and other incidents connected with it.

68. To what extent was the teacher's ability as a teacher judged by the success of her Christmas concert? Give details.

69. Was there much neighborhood rivalry as to which school could put on the best concert? Explain.

70. Tell about any other parties or special events held in particular years, which were a part of the school activities such as Valentine or Halloween parties, parents visiting the school, etc.

71. To what extent was the school building used as a community hall, for church, dances, concerts, organization meetings, special events, etc.? Describe.

72. Was the school yard used for school or community picnics, ball games, etc.? Describe.

GENERAL

73. What differences were there in the way the school was conducted in the first year you were here as compared with the country you came from?

74. Did any teachers or pupils from your district achieve distinction or become well known in later years? Give names and details.

75. Describe any special or unusual happenings or incidents in connection with school affairs in your district not already mentioned. (Use back of pages or extra sheets if necessary).
